subject: Computer Science
statement_full_text:
What interests me about computer science is how design choices at the smallest level from the design of an instruction set to the trade offs between speed and memory in algorithms can fundamentally shape the way systems work and evolve.  I have a particular interest in processor architecture, as it shows how design choices influence performance , energy efficiency and suitability for different purposes. Through hands-on experience with tools such as circuitverse, I have designed ALUs and registers to simulate CPU operations, broadening my understanding of how hardware executes instructions.
To stay up to date with the research in the field, I regularly watch channels such as veritasium and computerphile. One of my prominent interests is quantum computing, in which the use of superposition has the potential to revolutionise areas like financial modelling. This can be achieved by improving risk analysis, and has the potential to improve Reinforcement learning in training AI. Studying computer science will allow me the opportunity to build on my passion, develop my skills, and contribute something noteworthy to the field in the future.

Studying  computer science has enabled me to develop my skills in algorithm design to plan viable solutions as well as in  problem decomposition and understanding  the interlink between hardware and software. My NEA has also taught me about various software development processes available for projects and the importance of following commercial standards for coding. This prepares me for real world, professional opportunities. To further my studies I read an article from MIT about a company called Cloudian which developed AI optimised storage systems. It described how computation (the process of analysing data) can be done within the storage system rather than sending data to and from a separate processor. This reduced delays and decreased the training time required of AI models. It also discussed real time vectorisation where raw data is instantly converted into arrays that AI algorithms can understand during data loading. This article showed me that computer science isn't just creating good algorithms, but includes improving the systems that support them. 

Outside of education, I took part in a work experience at ARM offices in Sheffield. I learnt about their partnerships with charities such as UNICEF to use power efficient technology in remote regions. Some of their projects included quality monitoring in Laos and drone mapping in Malawi for flood predictions. This influenced me to research why ARM technologies are so successful in their work in off grid communities. I found out that the use of a RISC based processor (a processor that uses a small and optimised set of instructions)  and dynamic voltage scaling (a technique which adjusts a processor's voltage and frequency depending on workload) allows devices to function efficiently with a reduced power supply. I also learnt  about big.little architecture where high performance cores handled intensive tasks while low power cores handled simpler tasks. This reduced energy consumption without sacrificing performance. From work experience and my research I understood how developments in computer science can allow technology to have a real world impact, even in communities affected by the digital divide. Outside of my studies, I took part in weekly volunteering at my local charity shop.I also co-led the team for a milkshake stand during a charity event hosted at my school.These activities developed my organisational and teamwork skills. Balancing these commitments alongside my studies have greatly improved my time management. Overall they have given me the transferrable skills required for degree level computer science

SWFC - Working in a dynamic scale environment has improved my organisational skills as well as my teamwork and increased the efficiency of communications leading to an improved turnaround rate

feedback_items.weak_passage: What interests me about computer science is how design choices at the smallest level from the design of an instruction set to the trade offs between speed and memory in algorithms can fundamentally shape the way systems work and evolve.
feedback_items.your_feedback: First sentence is not as clear as you want it to be. That could apply to the majority of subjects - would you expect every choice to make a difference? Unless you had a slightly stronger point as to why specifically for computer science, maybe bring in an example where a change resulted in a specific impact.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Start by saying 'I am interested in computer science, in particular I have an interest in processor architecture' then explain with specific examples rather than vague statements about choices.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Through hands-on experience with tools such as circuitverse, I have designed ALUs and registers to simulate CPU operations
feedback_items.your_feedback: Rather than just listing out things you've done, I'd like to know more detail about how you went about designing it. 2 or 3 sentences per thing that you name drop - for example, 'I designed a particular ALU and it did this, and this was a really interesting experience.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add 2-3 sentences explaining the specific ALU you designed, what it did, and why the experience was interesting rather than just listing the tool and activity.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I regularly watch channels such as veritasium and computerphile.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You could say 'I regularly watch channels such as this' and we could both include the same thing, even though you actually watch and have an interest, and I don't. The difference is you need to show them what you're thinking as you're doing the stuff. Pick one particularly interesting case from Computer File and explain it and say why you think it's interesting.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Instead of just listing channels, explain one specific video or topic from Computer File that interested you and why it captured your attention.

feedback_items.weak_passage: One of my prominent interests is quantum computing, in which the use of superposition has the potential to revolutionise areas like financial modelling. This can be achieved by improving risk analysis, and has the potential to improve Reinforcement learning in training AI.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Cut filler like 'one of my prominent interests' and don't leave it to breathe. You started talking about how it can revolutionise financial modelling - go a couple sentences more in. How does it improve risk analysis specifically? What's the next step? It's not super clear what you mean.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand the financial modelling point with 2-3 more sentences explaining HOW quantum computing improves risk analysis specifically. Make the connection to reinforcement learning clearer rather than jumping between topics.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Studying computer science will allow me the opportunity to build on my passion, develop my skills, and contribute something noteworthy to the field in the future.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Just cut this sentence - you need to save characters to explain the other stuff in more detail.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this generic closing sentence and use the space to develop previous points.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Studying  computer science has enabled me to develop my skills in algorithm design to plan viable solutions as well as in  problem decomposition and understanding  the interlink between hardware and software.
feedback_items.your_feedback: That's just kind of like a summary point. I'd love you to expand that slightly rather than just giving the bullet point headline.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Provide specific examples of algorithms you've designed or problems you've decomposed rather than just summarizing skills in abstract terms.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My NEA has also taught me about various software development processes available for projects and the importance of following commercial standards for coding.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I'd like to hear more in detail about what you actually did, rather than just giving me the bullet point headline. If somebody else could include that exact sentence and it works for them, then it probably shouldn't be the only thing in your sentence. It's a good thesis point, but we need to expand it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Describe what your NEA project was, which specific development processes you used, and what you learned from implementing them.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This prepares me for real world, professional opportunities.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't really need that.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this obvious statement.

feedback_items.weak_passage: computation (the process of analysing data)
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't need to put the definition of that by the way, like they will definitely know that.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove the parenthetical definition - it's unnecessary for this audience.

feedback_items.weak_passage: It described how computation can be done within the storage system rather than sending data to and from a separate processor. This reduced delays and decreased the training time required of AI models. It also discussed real time vectorisation
feedback_items.your_feedback: That's the first area where you start developing a little bit more - you're saying it described this, and this leads to this. I wish you would link these two things better together rather than keeping them as two separate things.
feedback_items.strong_passage: It described how computation can be done within the storage system rather than sending data to and from a separate processor. This reduced delays and decreased the training time required of AI models.
feedback_items.why_strong: This is where you start developing properly - explaining what the article described and what the impact was, showing cause and effect.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This article showed me that computer science isn't just creating good algorithms, but includes improving the systems that support them.
feedback_items.your_feedback: A little bit more detail needed here. The whole NEA and article section needs more focus and development throughout.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand with one more specific point from the article rather than just a general conclusion.

feedback_items.weak_passage: a RISC based processor (a processor that uses a small and optimised set of instructions)  and dynamic voltage scaling (a technique which adjusts a processor's voltage and frequency depending on workload)
feedback_items.your_feedback: Don't put the bracket stuff in brackets that you've got, you don't need to include that. That sort of stuff is not what you want in there, so that will save you some characters as well.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove the parenthetical explanations - save characters by cutting these definitions.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This influenced me to research why ARM technologies are so successful in their work in off grid communities. I found out that the use of a RISC based processor... allows devices to function efficiently with a reduced power supply.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This thing about functioning efficiently with a reduced power supply is really interesting. Give me one more sentence, another point, and that would be a much better developed thing.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add one more sentence expanding on the efficiency aspect or providing another technical detail.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I also learnt  about big.little architecture where high performance cores handled intensive tasks while low power cores handled simpler tasks.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The Big Little architecture is interesting and it all ties in really well together. It all just feels like a tiny bit unfinished, just like literally 5%, and that would bring it to the next level.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add slightly more development to this interesting technical point.

feedback_items.weak_passage: From work experience and my research I understood how developments in computer science can allow technology to have a real world impact, even in communities affected by the digital divide.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You've already proved this through the things that you've talked about. I would simply lose that, unless you do a shorter version, because it feels a bit unnecessary.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this sentence as you've already demonstrated this understanding through your examples.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Balancing these commitments alongside my studies have greatly improved my time management. Overall they have given me the transferrable skills required for degree level computer science
feedback_items.your_feedback: I'd probably cut the last 2-3 sentences about time management and transferable skills - they're gonna know that already. Take those sentences you freed up and expand out other sections instead.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete the obvious concluding sentences about time management and use that space to develop technical content earlier in the statement.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Overall, you've got a lot of really good things in here. The problem is it's lacking in development. You've got almost too many points - you need 2-3 sentences per thing you mention rather than just name-dropping activities. Tell me more about your thoughts instead of moving on to the next thing.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus on fewer topics but develop each one deeply with 2-3 sentences explaining your thought process and what you learned.

subject: Accounting and Finance
statement_full_text:
I am fascinated by the way financial systems influence economic stability, business strategy, and the everyday lives of individuals. Studying A-level Mathematics, Economics, and Business has developed my ability to reason quantitatively and think critically about how markets operate. In Economics, exploring the relationship between interest rates and inflation allowed me to analyse the Bank of England's recent decision to maintain a restrictive base rate despite slowing GDP growth. This sparked my curiosity about the balance between monetary stability and economic expansion a trade-off at the heart of both macroeconomic policy and corporate finance. My personal research into unemployment and behavioural finance deepened my interest in how human decision-making diverges from rational models, and how this can impact investment behaviour, risk assessment, and policy effectiveness. I am particularly drawn to corporate finance because of its ability to shape long-term business resilience and innovation through strategic capital allocation.

Coming to the UK at the age of ten from a working-class background made me acutely aware of the effects of socioeconomic inequality. Observing how access to financial education, resources, and opportunity can vary so widely has motivated me to explore financially sustainable strategies to address these disparities. I see the study of Accounting and Finance not only as an academic pursuit, but also as a means of creating more equitable systems that balance profitability with social responsibility.

My work placement at CTMP Accountants Ltd gave me first-hand experience in bookkeeping, financial reporting, and tax return preparation. This sharpened my attention to accuracy and regulatory compliance, while also showing how financial statements influence business decisions. Analysing a client's cash flow patterns, for example, allowed me to see how liquidity management can prevent solvency issues in small firms. Winning a Bronze Award in the Senior UKMT Maths Challenge improved my ability to identify patterns, break down complex problems, and apply structured reasoning skills directly transferable to investment modelling and forecasting.

I expanded my exposure through virtual placements with PwC, KPMG, and Lloyd's Banking Group, where I explored portfolio diversification strategies and learned how scenario analysis can guide risk management. A "Maths in Action" lecture introduced me to statistical models that can be applied to market forecasting, while attending business and law conferences broadened my understanding of how regulation shapes financial markets. In my A-level Business coursework, I applied break-even analysis and net present value calculations to evaluate a manufacturing investment, weighing short-term liquidity pressures against long-term profitability. This combination of theoretical and applied work has reinforced my enthusiasm for integrating quantitative analysis with strategic judgement.

Leadership roles as a Year 11 prefect and now as a senior student leader have strengthened my organisational and problem-solving abilities. Coordinating events required budgeting, prioritising resources, and making decisions under time constraints  skills that mirror project management in corporate settings. Balancing these commitments with my studies has taught me to work efficiently under pressure, a quality essential in high-stakes financial environments.

At university, I plan to engage deeply with modules in financial modelling, corporate strategy, and econometrics, while participating in finance and investment societies. I aim to take part in consulting projects and trading simulations to apply my knowledge in competitive, real-world contexts. My long-term ambition is to qualify as a chartered financial officer, advancing to roles such as Financial Manager or CFO, where I can combine data-driven decision-making with strategic planning to foster sustainable growth. This degree offers the intellectual challenge and professional preparation necessary for me to achieve these goals while contributing meaningfully to the academic and extracurricular life of the university.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I am fascinated by the way financial systems influence economic stability, business strategy, and the everyday lives of individuals.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You say you're fascinated by how financial systems influence economic stability, but you don't tell me how. It doesn't really add anything, it's a little bit pointless. I would reshape that.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either explain HOW financial systems influence economic stability or remove this sentence and start with something more specific.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Studying A-level Mathematics, Economics, and Business
feedback_items.your_feedback: Small point - you don't capitalise subjects like mathematics, economics, business. You'll be capitalising anything that's like a modern language, but not those subjects.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove capitalization from subject names (mathematics, economics, business).

feedback_items.weak_passage: developed my ability to reason quantitatively and think critically about how markets operate
feedback_items.your_feedback: How did it teach you to reason quantitatively? I'd rather you went into an example - say a module in economics that you enjoyed was X, we had to do some calculations, and from this I found this interesting. I went and looked further at different statistical modelling that I might be working with at university. That's the general pattern you want to follow rather than telling me you've developed this ability with no evidence.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Provide a specific example of a calculation or module that developed your quantitative reasoning, then connect it to university-level work you've researched.

feedback_items.weak_passage: exploring the relationship between interest rates and inflation allowed me to analyse the Bank of England's recent decision
feedback_items.your_feedback: You can tell me the relationship actually, rather than just saying you explored it. Just say as interest rates increase, inflation is going to whatever. Then you can say maybe one other explanation or like one other impact that I found interesting was, and you can draw more things in from current day.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: State the actual relationship between interest rates and inflation, then add another specific impact or explanation that interested you from current events.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This sparked my curiosity about the balance between monetary stability and economic expansion a trade-off at the heart of both macroeconomic policy and corporate finance.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This kind of sentence reads like you're selling me the subjects - it's sort of commercial. I'd rather you just said this sparked my curiosity about the balance between stability and economic expansion. Go into more detail about what that trade-off is in your view, whether there's any way around it. You don't want to just summarise by saying this is important for economics, full stop.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove the 'at the heart of both...' phrase and instead explain what the trade-off actually is, whether you're looking at the UK specifically, and if there are ways around it.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My personal research into unemployment and behavioural finance deepened my interest in how human decision-making diverges from rational models
feedback_items.your_feedback: I would love to know what that research was, because I don't think you say. What was your original interest? What was your original understanding of this? Rather than saying it deepened your interest, tell me about the research itself.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Describe the actual research you conducted - what did you study, what sources did you use, what did you discover about how decision-making diverges from rational models?

feedback_items.weak_passage: and how this can impact investment behaviour, risk assessment, and policy effectiveness
feedback_items.your_feedback: It's very listy. It's just better to say this has an effect on this, and I find that interesting, rather than trying to summarise the entirety of your subject.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Pick one specific impact and explain it rather than listing three broad areas.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I am particularly drawn to corporate finance because of its ability to shape long-term business resilience and innovation through strategic capital allocation.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This sentence sounds a bit inauthentic. It doesn't sound like a particularly good reason to like corporate finance. Also, it's probably better not to mention corporate finance in your academic personal statement - they're not really going to care what kind of career you want to go into.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove or replace this sentence. Focus on academic interests rather than career-oriented statements about corporate finance.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Coming to the UK at the age of ten from a working-class background made me acutely aware of the effects of socioeconomic inequality. Observing how access to financial education, resources, and opportunity can vary so widely has motivated me to explore financially sustainable strategies to address these disparities.
feedback_items.your_feedback: It's only best to mention your background if you're going to directly link it to some main idea. You just say you saw some inequality full stop, then say this motivated you to explore financially sustainable strategies - but you don't mention what those strategies are or how you've been exploring them. The whole thing loses steam. Tell me what type of strategy you've been looking at, what you read in a paper, what podcast you're following, what series of books.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either cut this section or explain specific strategies you've researched and how you've explored them (papers, podcasts, books). Give the story of what you did next after noticing inequality.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I see the study of Accounting and Finance not only as an academic pursuit, but also as a means of creating more equitable systems that balance profitability with social responsibility.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I'm not sure that sentence really adds anything. It's another one of your summary sentence types.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this generic closing sentence.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My work placement at CTMP Accountants Ltd gave me first-hand experience in bookkeeping, financial reporting, and tax return preparation. This sharpened my attention to accuracy and regulatory compliance, while also showing how financial statements influence business decisions. Analysing a client's cash flow patterns, for example, allowed me to see how liquidity management can prevent solvency issues in small firms.
feedback_items.your_feedback: That seems pretty interesting, I thought that was good. Generally OK.
feedback_items.strong_passage: My work placement at CTMP Accountants Ltd gave me first-hand experience in bookkeeping, financial reporting, and tax return preparation. This sharpened my attention to accuracy and regulatory compliance, while also showing how financial statements influence business decisions. Analysing a client's cash flow patterns, for example, allowed me to see how liquidity management can prevent solvency issues in small firms.
feedback_items.why_strong: Good specific example with concrete details about the work placement and what was learned.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Winning a Bronze Award in the Senior UKMT Maths Challenge improved my ability to identify patterns, break down complex problems, and apply structured reasoning skills directly transferable to investment modelling and forecasting.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This part I don't like. It's a bit much to put in the personal statement. Can you ask your teacher to include this award in your reference? That would be a better place to put it so you have more space to talk about other things. Talking about your skills is not that useful.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this sentence and ask your teacher to mention the award in the reference instead. Use the space for more substantive content.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I expanded my exposure through virtual placements with PwC, KPMG, and Lloyd's Banking Group, where I explored portfolio diversification strategies and learned how scenario analysis can guide risk management.
feedback_items.your_feedback: That sounds good. Can you maybe expand a couple more sentences there? I think that'd be nice if you could just say a little bit more about what you learned.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add 2-3 sentences explaining what specific portfolio diversification strategies you explored or what you learned about scenario analysis.

feedback_items.weak_passage: A "Maths in Action" lecture introduced me to statistical models that can be applied to market forecasting, while attending business and law conferences broadened my understanding of how regulation shapes financial markets.
feedback_items.your_feedback: It's starting to sound like a list. Better if you can get into some of that forecasting and say look, this is the type of model that we worked with, and this is the conclusion that we found. You're just going straight into you attended conferences - you drop in that you learned how regulation shapes financial markets but could you talk about some of that regulation, how does it shape financial markets?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Choose one thing (the statistical models OR the regulation) and develop it with specific examples rather than listing multiple activities superficially.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In my A-level Business coursework, I applied break-even analysis and net present value calculations to evaluate a manufacturing investment, weighing short-term liquidity pressures against long-term profitability.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I wouldn't get too much into that actually, because that should maybe be in your reference if it can be. If not, I think you won't have enough characters to talk about this. If you have to lose it, I would say lose this section if you end up needing more space.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider removing this A-level coursework detail if you need space, especially if it can be mentioned in your reference.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This combination of theoretical and applied work has reinforced my enthusiasm for integrating quantitative analysis with strategic judgement.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Again, as I say, that is summary and that is listing yourself.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this generic summary sentence.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Leadership roles as a Year 11 prefect and now as a senior student leader have strengthened my organisational and problem-solving abilities. Coordinating events required budgeting, prioritising resources, and making decisions under time constraints  skills that mirror project management in corporate settings. Balancing these commitments with my studies has taught me to work efficiently under pressure, a quality essential in high-stakes financial environments.
feedback_items.your_feedback: That sounds good, but in here you are listing your skills again, so maybe take some of those out. We need to save space. These modules should have kind of come up earlier - when you say stuff like we did some statistical modelling that was really interesting, maybe there you could link in and say I am really interested in doing financial modelling at university as a result of this course. That's more natural rather than just lifting off I'm going to do all of these things at the end.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove some of the skill-listing. Consider moving module mentions to earlier sections where they connect naturally to activities rather than listing them at the end.

feedback_items.weak_passage: At university, I plan to engage deeply with modules in financial modelling, corporate strategy, and econometrics, while participating in finance and investment societies. I aim to take part in consulting projects and trading simulations to apply my knowledge in competitive, real-world contexts. My long-term ambition is to qualify as a chartered financial officer, advancing to roles such as Financial Manager or CFO, where I can combine data-driven decision-making with strategic planning to foster sustainable growth. This degree offers the intellectual challenge and professional preparation necessary for me to achieve these goals while contributing meaningfully to the academic and extracurricular life of the university.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This ambition stuff should be in the main body, not just shoved in at the end - it's more for you to know personally. That last sentence about 'this degree offers the intellectual challenge' - I would just get rid of that whole sentence. It's just more for yourself, not really telling the tutor much about how you think and what you've been doing.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this entire concluding paragraph. Move any relevant module interests to earlier sections where they naturally connect to your experiences. Remove career ambitions as they're not relevant for academic applications.

feedback_items.your_feedback: A lot of my questions while I'm reading your personal statement is like OK, but also, then what happened? How, and exactly what and why? So I think you're lacking a little bit on that side of stuff. Instead of telling me you developed abilities or you're fascinated by something, show me with evidence and examples.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Throughout the statement, replace claims about skills/interests with specific examples and evidence. Answer the questions: what exactly? how? why? what happened next?

subject: Chemical Engineering
statement_full_text:
The childlike thrill of solving a puzzle, piece by piece, experimenting with different structures in order to create a functional image, mirrors a key feature I see in Chemical Engineering. Operation by operation, calculating each mass balance, troubleshooting each ﬂow diagram, to ultimately create the most environmentally, economically and ethically efﬁcient process available. The dissection of complex systems, such as in a NileRed video on molecularly manipulating gloves into grape soda, initially crystallised my curiosity, and inspired me to start thinking about how everyday processes can be broken down and reﬁned, in order to provide a tangible impact. 

Ingenia's article on forever chemicals forced me to question my own effect environmentally - even through waterproof clothing. Gore-Tex, a well-known brand's famous waterproof technology contains PFAS, which I discovered can quickly pollute our bodies and our environment. Recognising PFAS structural resemblance to CFCs and having learned of their harmful effects, I was concerned about the harm wearing my everyday jacket caused. After further research, I was provided with a great example of Chemical Engineering, where I learned of the brand's research into a PFAS-free membrane using expanded polyethylene's microporous structure, allowing them to slowly achieve their 2050 carbon neutrality goal. This transition helped reshape the way I view my footprint, and rethink how things are made, not just used. 

Taking part in the CHAS programme led by Cambridge taught me to face a series of unprecedented calculations, in key areas like thermodynamics, and challenged my understanding of my A-level subjects. Ultimately, I presented a small lecture about green hydrogen. I researched and talked about large-scale hydrogen hubs, new production methods like photoelectrochemical water splitting, and hydrogen's potential across multiple industries, such as aviation, or current electric vehicle applications, like the Toyota Mirai, using measures like the TRL scale.  

Through my work experience at Pharmaron, I learned more about materials and was able to directly compare my school's synthesis of aspirin to a company on a manufacturing scale. After synthesising, I determined my purity using HPLC, and compared my data to reference data, and was able to gain around 95% purity. Further techniques like FTIR, XRPD, and microscopy, gave me insight on modern approaches in pharmacy, compared to me and my classmates using school lab resources. Scaling this up from a classroom level, exposed me to chemical challenges, such as maintaining purity white optimising reaction time, or temperature trade-offs. Ultimately, after formulating and testing the dissolution of my tablet, I conducted a report, which taught me the transformation of raw materials into a product suitable for human use, in a hands-on environment.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The childlike thrill of solving a puzzle, piece by piece, experimenting with different structures in order to create a functional image, mirrors a key feature I see in Chemical Engineering. Operation by operation, calculating each mass balance, troubleshooting each ﬂow diagram, to ultimately create the most environmentally, economically and ethically efﬁcient process available.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You do quite a lot of surrounding, descriptive stuff that doesn't really add much. The first two sentences in particular - I'd rather just have the definition of chemical engineering or some understanding of exactly what you're gonna study. This could probably be reduced to a quarter of the total length.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut the puzzle metaphor entirely. Start directly with the NileRed video as your entry point into chemical engineering, then expand from there.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The dissection of complex systems, such as in a NileRed video on molecularly manipulating gloves into grape soda, initially crystallised my curiosity
feedback_items.your_feedback: Turn this whole paragraph around and start with 'I became interested in chemical engineering when I saw a NileRed video on molecularly manipulating gloves into grape soda.' Add one more sentence explaining exactly what you saw in that video. Then go to a first year university textbook, find this particular topic, and use some of that material to expand and say you looked at this textbook and found it interesting. Link in something from current affairs or recent chemical engineering developments.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Start with the NileRed video directly (1 sentence), explain what you saw (1-2 sentences), then connect to university-level textbook content (2-3 sentences), and link to current research or applications (2-3 sentences).

feedback_items.weak_passage: Gore-Tex, a well-known brand's famous waterproof technology contains PFAS, which I discovered can quickly pollute our bodies and our environment... After further research, I was provided with a great example of Chemical Engineering, where I learned of the brand's research into a PFAS-free membrane
feedback_items.your_feedback: It's good, but it's too low level to talk about for the whole paragraph. Use it as your starting point and say you're interested in environmentally safe waterproof clothing, Gore-Tex is a great example. Don't say you researched more into the brand's particular thing - going into too much detail about Gore-Tex. Relate it to something higher level, either from a chemical engineering lecture from university level, or an academic paper discussing similar ideas. Maybe talk about net effects on the environment, is it good, is it bad, are there better materials, are they developing something better?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Reduce Gore-Tex discussion to 2-3 sentences as a starting point. Then connect to university-level concepts, academic papers, or broader environmental materials science rather than staying focused on the brand.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I presented a small lecture about green hydrogen.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Don't call it small. You've done a good job clearly with it. Just say 'I gave a lecture'.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Change 'small lecture' to 'lecture' - be more confident.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I researched and talked about large-scale hydrogen hubs, new production methods like photoelectrochemical water splitting, and hydrogen's potential across multiple industries, such as aviation, or current electric vehicle applications, like the Toyota Mirai, using measures like the TRL scale.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're just listing - there's new production methods like this, and then this, and then this, and then this. We don't want a list. We just want to choose one and then go into depth within it. Talk more about the conclusion of your lecture. Maybe talk about some of the methodology or the research you did in more detail rather than just listing topics.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Choose ONE aspect (e.g., photoelectrochemical water splitting) and develop it deeply with methodology, findings, and conclusions from your lecture rather than listing multiple topics.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I learned more about materials and was able to directly compare my school's synthesis of aspirin to a company on a manufacturing scale. After synthesising, I determined my purity using HPLC, and compared my data to reference data
feedback_items.your_feedback: I would veer away from talking about things like you synthesize something, you determine something. It's fine to talk about OK these are the methods involved and I find it really interesting. But then just go straight on to talk about what kind of more interesting experiments you're gonna conduct at university rather than going into too much detail about this classroom level stuff.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Briefly mention the synthesis methods (1-2 sentences max), then transition to discussing university-level experiments or research you're interested in pursuing.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Overall, I think you've done a really good job. This is a good start. But I would probably reduce this to about 20% of what you've written - at least half or maybe a quarter of the total length. You do quite a lot of surrounding, descriptive stuff that doesn't really add much. I actually prefer this to some statements where I see too many high-level ideas coming in, but you're just lacking that development.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Keep the authentic content but drastically reduce wordiness. Aim to condense current content to 25-50% of its length, then use saved space to develop ideas more deeply with university-level sources and current research.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The general structure you want to take: start directly by saying I like this, this is where I started, this is what I then went on to do, and this is how it relates to my field of study, and this is why I want to study it. Go to first year university textbooks and find particular topics to expand out. Look at academic papers that have come out discussing similar ideas.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: For each section: (1) State your interest directly, (2) Give specific example/starting point, (3) Connect to university-level textbook content, (4) Link to academic papers or current research, (5) Explain why you want to study this.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Be more confident. The way you're talking about some of the stuff, it seems like you're not too confident and sure of yourself, but you can be. You've done a great job and you've clearly learned a lot and you're clearly interested. You have a very authentic base - I prefer this to statements with too many high-level ideas but no development.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove hedging language ('small lecture', uncertain phrasing). State your accomplishments and interests directly and confidently.
feedback_items.strong_passage: You've got a very authentic base. I prefer this to some of the stuff where I see too many high-level ideas coming in.
feedback_items.why_strong: The feedback acknowledges the student's genuine interest and authentic engagement with the subject, which is a strong foundation.

subject: Law
statement_full_text:
Question 1 
During  the  political  upheaval  of  Hong  Kong,  I  stood  there  watching  the  society  I  grew  up  in struggle  with  legal  and  political  instability.  Through  these  turbulent  times  as tensions between China and Hong Kong intensified, I sought to comprehend the roots of this political dissonance. It made me aware of the stark differences in the legal frameworks of China and western countries (including Hong Kong). Whereas most countries are governed by the rule of law, China operates under rule by law. In reading Bingham's The Rule of Law and attending law tutorials, I learned about  his  8  principles,  considered  a  cornerstone  of  legal  philosophy,  which  China's  system contradicts entirely, therefore answering my initial question. Works by Prof. Cohen and Shitong Qiao  further  deepened  my  understanding.  Qiao,  in  particular,  highlighted how justice in China often emerges not through formal legal rights but through social norms, blurring the line between legality  and  legitimacy.  However,  if  such  a  system delivers economic success and order, can it truly  be  called  unjust?  When  I  revisit  Bingham's  ideas,  which  revolve  around  liberty,  fairness and  equality.  I  understood  that  without  legal  restraint,  governments  who remain above the law can't  deliver  true  justice.  Acknowledging  its  economic  success,  can  one truly admire a system that disregards justice to its citizens. Having explored this issue, it reshaped my views on law as plainly a set of rules, but a means to protect our values.  

Question 2  
Through  A  Level  Psychology,  I  learned  about  conformity.  Why  do  people  conform?  It's fear—fear  of  consequences,  social  backlash  and  authority  figures.  In  recent  years,the government, also the authority figure, has intensified hate speech regulations increasingly, often determining the line between free speech and hate speech, restraining what people can or cannot say,  now  even  arresting  citizens  for  tweets,  memes  and  comments.  At  the  same  time,  social media plays an influential role in shaping our culture and social behavior. However, it also brings unspoken pressures, where many people are afraid to share their thoughts, as harassment, public backlash,  or  algorithmic  silencing  often  leads  them  to  self  censor.  Although  this  may  not constitute  direct  state censorship, such pressures raise critical questions about the true extent of free  speech.  Timothy  Garton  Ash,  in  his  book,  refers  to  this  as  the  "iceberg  effect"—an atmosphere  in which people self-censor, not because they are legally compelled to, but because they fear the consequences of speaking freely. Therefore, they conform to the norm. The biggest factor  in  why  this  book  resonated  with me is that it is relatively new, quite focused on internet speech, and takes into account more recent issues. What I took most to heart was his perspective of 'combating harmful speech with more speech', and his liberal stance on free expression, both are views which lots of youtube political figures I watch hold. 

Question 3 

Participating  in  Mooting  and  Mock Trial Competition solidified my interest in law, it made me realize how the phrasing of a sentence or narrative can make or break a case. As Bryan A. Garner says, "Words are the lawyers' tools. The sharpness of these tools can cut both ways." This taught me how vital crafting a compelling opening and closing statements are. How I sway   the jury by relying  on  concise  phrasing  and  storytelling  to  frame  the  narrative  really  appealed  to  me.  In Jordan Peterson's Rule 10 of 12 Rules for Life, "Precision in Speech" resonated with me not only in  day  to  day  life,  but  especially  in  cross-examination;  it  shows  how  precise  questioning  can guide  a  witness's  response,  pinpointing inconsistencies, strengthening your credibility. Through trial  and  error,  I  learned  to  adapt  beyond  prepared  scripts  to  suit  different  witnesses  and  to strategically  challenge  contradictions  when  they  arise.  Most  importantly,  the  courtroom-like experience  allowed  me  to  fully  embrace  the  role  of  a  lawyer,  fueling  my  desire  to  continue exploring the legal field. 

Many people outside the legal profession talk about its shine and glamour, expecting everyone to be  like Harvey Specter, which can't be further from the truth. During my internships, I handled filings,  drafted  documents  and  communicated  with  clients.  The  work  required  real effort, long hours  and without glamour, but it also demanded precision, perseverance, and client interaction that  wasn't  all  pretty.  I  had  already  developed  resilience  through  sports  and  precision  through music,  but  these  experiences  taught  me  how  to  grind,  how  to  complete  what  many  would consider  monotonous  work,  without  the  adrenaline  fuelling  yourself,  and  yet  maintain  high standards, which really allowed me to grasp the day to day of a lawyer.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I've looked at your personal statement. The law applicants this year are such a strong batch and yours is equally good. Your version is not bad, it's good. There's nothing inherently super wrong with it. If you're happy with it, you can just stick with it. This is just what could potentially elevate the statement.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Your personal statement is good overall - it's a strong batch for law applicants this year.
feedback_items.why_strong: The overall quality is solid with good content and structure.

feedback_items.weak_passage: During the political people of Hong Kong, I stood there watching the society I grew up in struggle with legal and political instability. Through these turbulent times, as tensions between China and Hong Kong intensified, I sought to comprehend the roots of this political dissonance.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The first two sentences are not the best. I don't think you need all of that to say that one thought. I prefer you came in with something more unique to you - you can actually pick up on something specific. Say the political upheaval in Hong Kong which happened in one year, I noticed one particular event from this, I sought to understand where this political distance began. That would be better than just saying there's some general instability, general turbulent times, general tensions.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace the first two sentences with one specific sentence: mention the year, a particular event you witnessed, and your specific question. Remove generic phrases like 'turbulent times' and 'intensified tensions'.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In reading Bingham's The Rule of Law and attending law tutorials, I learned about his eight principles considered a cornerstone of legal philosophy, which China's system contradicts entirely. Therefore, answering my initial question.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is a terrible sentence, I'll just be honest with you. The structure of that sentence, you need to change that. It's just absolutely not clear at all. I don't even know what your initial question might be - is that where the roots of the political dissonance come from? Absolutely unclear. The link to law is weak - if I didn't know you were applying for law and without the last paragraph, I'd probably think you're applying for politics or international relations.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Completely restructure this sentence. Clearly state what your initial question was, then explain how Bingham's 8 principles answer it specifically. Add more concrete discussion of legal definitions and frameworks to strengthen the law connection.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I think the general idea that you've included here is really interesting - I've not seen it before in other statements, you've done well there. You do need more concrete things and more discussion of the definitions in law or frameworks that exist in law. Something more along those lines.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand with more legal frameworks, definitions, and concrete legal concepts rather than staying at the political/philosophical level.
feedback_items.strong_passage: The general idea about comparing China's legal system with rule of law is interesting and I've not seen it before in other statements.
feedback_items.why_strong: Original topic choice that demonstrates genuine intellectual curiosity.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Through  A  Level  Psychology,  I  learned  about  conformity.  Why  do  people  conform?  It's fear—fear  of  consequences,  social  backlash  and  authority  figures.  In  recent  years,the government, also the authority figure, has intensified hate speech regulations increasingly, often determining the line between free speech and hate speech, restraining what people can or cannot say,  now  even  arresting  citizens  for  tweets,  memes  and  comments.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Your writing is a little bit summary-like. There's not a lot of evidence, particularly in the first half of this paragraph when you're discussing conformity. This kind of bold claim without any evidence and support is not the best - you want to substantiate a little bit. Things like 'in recent years the government has intensified hate speech' - I'm thinking which government, what authority figure, how have they done that? It's just kind of anecdotal, like your opinion. It doesn't play that well in a very academic setting.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add specific evidence: which government, which regulations, specific cases of arrests. Cite psychology studies on conformity rather than making unsupported claims. Ground the discussion in concrete examples and research.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You do a lot better in areas where you're talking about works by Professor Cohen and Shitong Qiao, when you're talking about Bingham and bringing in actual references - that works a lot better.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Works by Prof. Cohen and Shitong Qiao further deepened my understanding. When you're bringing in actual references like Bingham.
feedback_items.why_strong: Good use of academic sources and proper referencing strengthens the argument.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In Jordan Peterson's Rule 10 of 12 Rules for Life, "Precision in Speech" resonated with me
feedback_items.your_feedback: I wouldn't personally value that as a text, to be honest with you. If you could replace that with something else, like a little bit more academic, that would be good.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace Jordan Peterson with a more academic legal source on communication or advocacy.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Many people outside the legal profession talk about its shine and glamour, expecting everyone to be  like Harvey Specter, which can't be further from the truth. During my internships, I handled filings,  drafted  documents  and  communicated  with  clients.  The  work  required  real effort, long hours  and without glamour, but it also demanded precision, perseverance, and client interaction that  wasn't  all  pretty.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This last paragraph is not really the best. This is all very like OK, but these are just thoughts. It would be better if you could just cut that out and include something more concrete. This entire last paragraph doesn't help you because all it does is talk about like you handled filings, drafted documents, communicated - it required real effort, long hours, without glamour, demanded precision, perseverance, client interaction. That's you know, this is all just a list of things. You don't need to tell them that.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete the entire opening about Harvey Specter. Replace the list of generic tasks with specific examples: what client interaction was particularly interesting? Where did you have to persevere? Give concrete examples rather than listing abstract qualities.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I've developed it through sport... precision through music
feedback_items.your_feedback: If you can just tell me, include a sentence, be like look I've been playing football for 12 years or something like that. That's gonna be more useful than that last paragraph.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add one specific sentence about your sport or music activity rather than vague references to 'sports' and 'music'.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Participating  in  Mooting  and  Mock Trial Competition solidified my interest in law
feedback_items.your_feedback: That paragraph with the mooting stuff - if you could include proper arguments and cases that you looked at, that would be more useful. It reads a little bit more like a closing summary type thing. You need to show what cases you researched, what arguments you made, where you went to find your sources and evidence.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add specific details about cases you researched, legal arguments you constructed, and sources you consulted for the mooting competition.

feedback_items.your_feedback: As a whole, your writing is a little bit summary-like. There's some evidence but not enough throughout - you're lacking in supporting points, lacking in clear cut conclusions, and it's not as law-like as I would want it to be. You make a lot of use of sentences where you're saying 'acknowledging or reading or doing something' and then you have multiple clauses. It's quite confusing. We like direct, we like succinct, we like concise. If you can say something in fewer words or split up ideas, that's better.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Throughout the statement: (1) Add more supporting evidence, (2) Draw clearer conclusions, (3) Simplify sentence structures - make them more direct and concise, (4) Make the content more focused on legal concepts and frameworks.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Acknowledging its economic success, can one truly admire a system that disregards justice to its citizens?
feedback_items.your_feedback: That's not the best grammar in the world. You do this kind of thing where you're saying acknowledging or reading or doing something, and then you have multiple clauses. It's just quite confusing. There should never be a sentence in here where I think 'what's that talking about?'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Simplify the sentence structure. Split into two clear sentences: one about economic success, one about justice. Avoid complex subordinate clauses.

feedback_items.your_feedback: So as a whole, it's not bad at all. Definitely 7.5, I'd give you on that scale of statements. You're definitely doing very, very well. Particularly I really like your writing style in general - it's just is it perfectly suitable for when you need to pack a 4000 character thing with as much information as possible? Potentially take another look.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: While your writing style is good, consider whether it's optimized for the character limit. Can you be more concise while adding more substance?
feedback_items.strong_passage: I really like your writing style in general.

subject: Law
statement_full_text:
Question 1 

I became curious about   exploring the political dissonance between Hong Kong and China when I  saw   peers  of  mine  were  protesting.  It  shined  a  light  on  the  moral  foundations  of  two  legal philosophies:  rule  of  law  and rule by law. As courts in China lack judicial independence, I saw first hand how the Chinese Communist Party weaponized the legal system  to persecute people it deemed threats to the regime. Articles by Donald Clarke deepened my understanding on how the vagueness  ingrained  in  Chinese  laws  creates  uncertainty,  undermining  citizens'  clarity  on their rights. However, if the legal system employed by China delivers economic success and order, can it  truly  be  called  immoral?   In  search  of  answers,  I  read Sir Tom Bingham's The Rule of Law, which provides   a framework on a fair legal system. Reading this piece lead me to conclude that,  as  the  Chinese  government  operates  without  legal restraint from the judiciary, it cannot deliver true justice. Thinking deeply about this issue has reshaped my view of law as not merely a set of rules, but rather a means to protect our values. 

Question 2 

In summer 2025, I attended an Oxford Law summer course, where I examined Timothy Garton Ash's  "Free  Speech".  In  this  piece,  the  author  defends  classical  liberal  values  for  free speech. Specifically,  he  argues  that  speech  should  be  countered  with  more  speech,  a  stance  which strongly  resonates  with  me.  While  it  is  clear  that  speech  can  inflict  significant  psychological harm,  it  raises  a  fundamental  question,  should  a  fundamental  human  right  be  curtailed  in  the interest of the possibility of causing offence? 

Ash  discusses  this  when  he  mentions  China's  "Orwellian"  censorship  apparatus,  in  which  the government controls every aspect of online content in the name of national security. Notably, this censorship  apparatus  was  used  to  prevent  dissenters  from  exposing  globally  significant  news, like when covid 19 whistleblowers disappeared trying to warn people of the spread of virus. .  

My fascination with the topic of free speech led me to champion this issue in  my school's ECHR MUN.  As  a  UK  delegate,  I  researched  Liberty  and Others v. United Kingdom and Big Brother Watch and Others v. United Kingdom, to understand how a balance between individual rights and collective  security  can  be  achieved.  Both  cases  revolved  around  Article  8  as  a  qualified right. Meaning  for  purposes  of  national  security,  the  government  may  interfere  with  an  individual's privacy  if  the  interference  is  subject  to  rigorous  checks  and  adequate  legal  safeguards.  This reshaped  my  perspective  on  how  the  law  balances  the  protection  of  civil  liberties  with  state interests. 

Question 3 

Participating  in  a  Mooting  Competition  solidified  my  interest  in  law.  I  learned  that  good advocacy  requires  building  a  compelling  narrative  and  engaging  emotionally  with  jurors, securing  a  win  through  engaging  on  both a personal and professional level. In the finals of the mooting  competition,  my  team  represented  the  defence  in a rape case involving 2 drunk teens, where  we  focused  on  the  arguement  of  mutual  intoxication.  During  cross  examination,  we established the victim's   state of intoxication and acts of apparent consent. By demonstrating the level of intoxication of both parties, behaviours the victim exhibited as well as   her fondness of the defendant, we were successful in raising reasonable doubt, resulting in our win. In navigating this  case,  where  evidence  was  scarce  and  definitions  were  murky,  I  realized  that  a  successful   lawyer is a good storyteller who understands the jury and their reservations 

In addition to my experience in mooting, I witnessed the power of interpersonal dynamics in  my internship  at  Lester  Dominic  Solicitors,  where I sat in on client meetings and watched partners change their tactics when dealing with different clients. During an execution of will I witnessed, a heated argument erupted regarding discrepancies in the amount inherited. The partner, whom I shadowed, responded calmly and provided solutions quickly. It showed me once again that being a  lawyer  isn't  just  about  knowing the law but also the client. The complementary nature of the two skills propels me to study law.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Sorry for the late feedback. I finally managed to have a look and wanted to give you some thoughts. First off, your writing is really, really good. I like your writing style a lot. It's definitely one of the up there ones. If I had to put this statement on a 0 to 10 scale of all the law statements I've looked at this year, I would say this is a strong 7.5-8. This year all the law kids are just really head and shoulders above the rest.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Your writing is really, really good. I like your writing style a lot. Strong 7.5-8 out of 10.
feedback_items.why_strong: Excellent writing quality and strong overall structure for a law application.

feedback_items.your_feedback: There's not actually anything inherently wrong with it - you don't have any particular red flags or things I would tell you to change that wouldn't just be my opinion. You've got well-developed ideas, you've got good sections. I'm just gonna raise a few questions for you to maybe rethink.
feedback_items.strong_passage: You've got well-developed ideas, you've got good sections.
feedback_items.why_strong: Strong foundation with good development and structure.

feedback_items.weak_passage: However, if the legal system employed by China delivers economic success and order, can it  truly  be  called  immoral?
feedback_items.your_feedback: Using a rhetorical question in a personal statement is not the wisest because these statements are not there to make the tutor think. It's more to get your view. I think that's a bit of a stylistic choice, but I'm not sure that's the best use of your statement. I would prefer that you actually expanded that out and told me specifically what you think.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace the rhetorical question with a direct statement of your view. Expand with 2-3 sentences explaining your position on whether economic success justifies an immoral legal system.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You have a slightly more narrative style compared to some of the others, which means yours isn't as content dense as other people's. Other people are managing to include more sections and more developed sections. If I had one suggestion - potentially you could reduce some of these sections down and add a bit more, because it's not that dense. I'm sure you're a good enough writer that you could do that.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Condense the narrative elements and add another section or expand existing sections with more academic content. Increase information density throughout.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I think that paragraph's good.
feedback_items.strong_passage: The first paragraph about Hong Kong and China's legal systems is good.
feedback_items.why_strong: Well-developed exploration of comparative legal systems.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Same with the second one. I think these sections are good.
feedback_items.strong_passage: The second section on free speech and Timothy Garton Ash is good.
feedback_items.why_strong: Good academic engagement with contemporary free speech issues.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In the finals of the mooting  competition,  my  team  represented  the  defence  in a rape case involving 2 drunk teens, where  we  focused  on  the  arguement  of  mutual  intoxication.  During  cross  examination,  we established the victim's   state of intoxication and acts of apparent consent. By demonstrating the level of intoxication of both parties, behaviours the victim exhibited as well as   her fondness of the defendant, we were successful in raising reasonable doubt, resulting in our win.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The main part I have an issue with is this mooting competition. It's quite a controversial thing you're explaining. You're going for a very academic degree course, but as a lawyer there's still ethics involved. If you could rephrase to have more of an academic angle - as you're explaining this, you're saying we established this and that, but it's not like 'we looked at these past cases and used that as precedent' or mentioning articles you read. You haven't mentioned any sources that inspired you or how you knew this would work within the confines of law.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add academic framing: mention specific cases you used as precedent, articles about consent law and intoxication you researched, legal frameworks you applied. Explain the legal reasoning and sources rather than just describing what you did tactically.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I realized  that  a  successful   lawyer is a good storyteller who understands the jury and their reservations
feedback_items.your_feedback: Your conclusion being 'a successful lawyer is a good storyteller' - that's very much a practical element. At Oxford, LSE, and these academic universities, they don't particularly care about your career. It's really about the study of the law. This section is very not academic enough and reads as a little bit too controversial.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace the practical career-focused conclusion with an academic insight about consent law, standards of evidence, or legal principles you learned from studying the case.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In addition to my experience in mooting, I witnessed the power of interpersonal dynamics in  my internship  at  Lester  Dominic  Solicitors,  where I sat in on client meetings and watched partners change their tactics when dealing with different clients. During an execution of will I witnessed, a heated argument erupted regarding discrepancies in the amount inherited. The partner, whom I shadowed, responded calmly and provided solutions quickly. It showed me once again that being a  lawyer  isn't  just  about  knowing the law but also the client.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The last section is a little bit lazy on your part. You kind of go away from doing really nuanced argument making and detailed content and explanation. You're just saying I sat in on client meetings, they changed their tactics - OK cool. Heated arguments regarding discrepancies - OK. He responded calmly and provided solutions - that's not really anything, is it? That whole last section doesn't add a whole lot of value.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace this generic description with specific examples: what client interaction was particularly interesting legally? What solutions were provided and why? What legal issues arose? Give examples showing legal substance rather than just storytelling about interpersonal skills.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The complementary nature of the two skills propels me to study law.
feedback_items.your_feedback: That last paragraph reads a little bit more like a closing summary type thing. So that whole question three I would personally work on.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this generic concluding sentence. Replace with substantive legal content.

feedback_items.your_feedback: If you change that last question three section, I think you're gonna be left with a fair amount of space anyway to include one more bit. You could attempt to reduce some of that narrative quality and include tiny bit more development, but ultimately if you change that last question three, you'll have space.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: After revising Q3 to be more academic and less narrative, use the freed space to either add a new section or deepen existing sections with more legal analysis.

feedback_items.your_feedback: This is just my opinion. You've done well here. Definitely 7.5 on that scale of statements. You're definitely doing very, very well. Particularly I really like your writing style in general. It's just is it perfectly suitable for when you need to pack a 4000 character thing with as much information as possible? Potentially take another look.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider whether your narrative style, while engaging, is the most efficient use of the character limit. Could you convey the same ideas more densely?
feedback_items.strong_passage: I really like your writing style in general.
feedback_items.why_strong: Natural, engaging writing that draws the reader in.
